ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] State variable combinations

A.J.,

You're right, it should result in an error condition when an  
unsupported property pair is specified.  I'll look into it...

Dave


On Dec 11, 2003, at 10:00 AM, aaronjosephsimon wrote:

>
> Dear Dr. Goodwin,
>
> This is my first post to the group; first a few words about myself.
> I am the "Energy Systems Analyst" with GCEP (Global Climate and
> Energy Project - for more info see http://gcep.stanford.edu) at
> Stanford University.  My work involves modeling of energy systems,
> advising graduate students and assessment of energy analysis
> software.  I do some work with Brooks Moses, Matt Svrcek and Patrick
> Caton (all members of the users group).
>
> I've been working on writing an interface for cantera/MATLAB that
> will use "lightweight" objects (see Brooks's post of 8/18/2003) and
> that will be accessible to graduate students (1st year master's
> level) in a class on thermodynamic modeling.  I've noticed that
> Cantera has a limited number of ways to set state variables.  For
> example, one can set Temperature and Pressure simultaneously, but
> not Temperature and Entropy.  While it was relatively easy to write
> my own functions to perform the appropriate calculations, it is a
> bit confusing that Cantera accepts the command to set said variables:
>
> gas = gri30
> s0 = entropy_mass(gas)
> T0 = temperature(gas)
> s1 = s0
> T1 = T0 + 100
> set(gas,'T',T1,'S',s1)
>
> but returns no warning that temperature was set, entropy input was
> ignored, and density was held fixed.
>
> I see that this "quirk" is referenced to some extent in the C++
> users guide, but it is my opinion that the interface should also
> return a message when it is unable to appropriately respond to the
> user's input.
>
> Let me know if there is any way that I can help.
>
> -A.J. Simon
>
>
